text: Patch bump is for no API changes (only bug fixes); minor bump is for API additions; major bump is for API subtractions or breaking changes.

recipient.name: Steve Agalloco

text: 0.X.Y versions give you the opportunity to figure out your public API. If someone really wants stability, they should avoid 0.X.Y gems.

recipient.description: Professional fanatic
recipient.name: Steve Agalloco

sender.description: Write code. Not too much. Mostly Ruby.
sender.name: Erik Michaels-Ober

text: The theory is, it's okay to make backward incompatible changes in minor releases if you're < 1.0.0, since you never promised a stable API.

recipient.description: Professional fanatic
recipient.name: Steve Agalloco

sender.description: Write code. Not too much. Mostly Ruby.
sender.name: Erik Michaels-Ober

text: SemVer gives you some leeway to break these rules when you're < version 1.0.0 but once you release version 1.0.0, you need to follow them.

recipient.description: Professional fanatic
recipient.name: Steve Agalloco

sender.description: Write code. Not too much. Mostly Ruby.
sender.name: Erik Michaels-Ober

text: Given X.Y.Z, bump Z for bug fixes, Y for new features (backward compatible), and X for breaking API changes (backward incompatible).
